rename.to: [BUG] SignatureTransformer and SignatureClassifier was incorrect, erroneously transpose numpy3D arrays

issue.title: [ENH] Transformers module full refactor - part IV, `panel` module (3rd batch)

labels.name: refactor
labels.description: Restructuring without changing its external behavior. Neither fixing a bug nor adding a feature.

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR refactors more transformers in the `transformations` module to the new interface, and continues #2253.
This is part IV - working on the `transformations.panel` module.

For all transformers in this PR, the following was carried out:
* inheritance parent is now `BaseTransformer`
* adding tags as appropriate
* moving logic to underscore methods `_fit`, `_transform`, and `_inverse_transform` (where applicable)
* removal of check/conversion logic which is already covered by `BaseTransformer`
* linting and cleaning up docstrings

Reviewers should focus on individual transformers and the general pattern.

This PR also includes:
* a fix for https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2374, by removing the transposition of numpy arrays throughout the signature transformer module and in `SignatureClassifier`

body:
Hello,

So the signature module was definitely working fine, but I appreciate some things have needed to be changed around.

So we always work with paths of shape [N, L, C] whereas sktime uses [N, C, L]. I took the lazy route of just flipping the C, L axes in the SignatureTransformer class and keeping everything the same as my existing stuff for the remainder of the code. I realise this makes the augmentation classes usable only via `SignatureTransformer` that handles the axes flipping. If it is desired for them to become general classes then they need adapting. 

`SignatureClassifier` is just a wrapper around `SignatureTransformer`. So they are not mixed up since `SignatureClassifier` just calls `SignatureTransformer` which flips the axes and performs the signature operations. Thus is does not need to happen in `SignatureClassifier`.

One option, which appears to be the one taken, would perform a transpose for each of the augmentations, but this must also happen in the `esig.stream2sig/stream2logsig` function - it appears not to have been added to the`esig` bits. 

I don't understand what this issue with depth is. The new code just seems to change the `depth` attribute to `sig_depth` but then call `depth = self.sig_depth` in the transform function. Not sure why this was necessary.

I see, thanks for confirming!

I did the flipping in this PR on all the components too:
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/2369
I hope this is still correct?

>I don't understand what this issue with depth is.

Constructor must write all parameters to self, *to a parameter of the same name*, or it will not be scikit-learn compliant (e.g., will throw an error if you attempt to print).

Doing the flips as described looks fine. It would perhaps be a bit neater to implement as an `axflip` decorator of some description, but up to you of course. Neater still would of course just be to rewrite them for [N, C, L] arrays.

The bit that is missing is
```
signature = np.stack(
    [transform(x[window.start : window.end]) for x in data]
).reshape(data.shape[0], -1)
```
needs to go to
```
signature = np.stack(
    [transform(x[window.start : window.end].T) for x in data]
).reshape(data.shape[0], -1)
```
since currently `x` would be of shape `[C, W]` where `C` the number of channels and `W` is the length of the window due to the axflip at the start. `esig` requires `[W, C]`.

Regarding depth, in that case, it would be neater to ignore `depth` altogether and just to call `self.sig_depth`.

>It would perhaps be a bit neater to implement as an axflip decorator 

I think it would be neater if the internal code would just use the right axes.

The "systematic" way, i.e., if it occurs often, would be the introduction of an mtype `numpy3D_flipped` or similar, since input/output conversion concerns are managed via `convert` in the `datatypes` module, currently.
A decorator would duplicate the locus of this concern and would not be preferable.

> The bit that is missing is

In the PR?

Would you kindly mind leaving a comment there, if it is missing?

my preference would have been to leave it all as is (if it aint broke...) but make the helper functions that require the  [N, L, C] private, then to raise an issue to refactor it all to work with  [N, C, L] to see if anyone wants to take it on.
I will happily sort out the conversion, but would have to be next week

> if it aint broke...

PS: as the refactor apparently uncovered, it *was* broke all along? At least in parts...

I consider this a positive about the refactor, not a negative.
Ah I misunderstood, I thought @jambo6 said it was fine before. @MatthewMiddlehurst this will impact our pipeline results

> Ah I misunderstood, I thought @jambo6 said it was fine before

He did, but now I think he changed his opinion?
As all wise people, in the wake of sufficient evidence...

It was working before changes, so if you used it before this there shouldn't be an issue. 

If the dimensions were the wrong way round, trust me you'd realise it. Feature dimension would scale exponentially with length which would be a disaster in general.

`esig` expects paths of shape `[length, channels]`, so I'm pretty sure the change must be
```
signature = np.stack(
    [transform(x[:, window.start : window.end].T) for x in data]
).reshape(data.shape[0], -1)
```
assuming data is shape `[batch, channels, length]` due to dimension flips at the start.

However, @fkiraly has said this change did not pass the tests and reverted back to how it was before. Now I'm pretty sure it cant be what it was before and it must mean its a problem with my tests not picking this up, however I don't know why it fails with the suggested approach. I'd need to see the test error to understand why./
